data.title: James Buchanan and Harriet Lane Johnston Papers
data.meta_description: A chronology of key events in the lives of James Buchanan (1791-1868), representative and senator from Pennsylvania, secretary of state, and fifteenth president of the United States, and his niece and White House hostess Harriet Lane Johnston (1830-1903).
data.text:
Elected to the Pennsylvania House of Representatives as a Federalist Party candidate

Death of fianc√©e, Ann Coleman, shortly after she ended her engagement to Buchanan

United States Representative from Pennsylvania. Buchanan initially represented the Federalist factions, but aligned with the Democratic Party of Andrew Jackson in 1828.

Secretary of state in James K. Polk's administration. Twice requested appointments to the United States Supreme Court in September 1845 and June 1846, respectively, only to withdraw the requests later.

Defeated by Franklin Pierce for nomination as presidential candidate of the Democratic Party

Coauthor of Ostend Manifesto with John Y. Mason and Pierre Soule, American minsters to France and Spain, respectively. The manifesto advocated the purchase or seizure of Cuba from Spain.

Nominated by the Democratic Party as presidential candidate, with John C. Breckinridge of Kentucky nominated as vice president

Dred Scott decision issued by the United States Supreme Court, two days after Buchanan's inauguration. Declared Missouri Compromise (1820) unconstitutional and discounted rights of African Americans.

Buchanan administration confronted with disputes in Kansas over the legality of slavery within the prospective new state. Buchanan supported the Lecompton Constitution authorizing slavery. Kansas admitted as a free state in January 1861.

Abraham Lincoln elected as president; the first president to represent the new Republican Party

South Carolina seceded from the union, and precipitated negotiations over reinforcement of Major Robert Anderson's forces in Union-held Fort Sumter in Charleston harbor. Six additional southern states seceded before end of Buchanan's administration in March.

Failed attempt by the Star of the West to resupply Fort Sumter

Published Mr. Buchanan's Administration on the Eve of the Rebellion. New York: D. Appleton

Became the ward of her uncle, James Buchanan, after death of her father Elliott Tole Lane in November 1840

Enrolled in the Academy of the Visitation, Georgetown, D.C.

Lived in London, England, while James Buchanan served as the American minister to the Court of St. James
